   ECG:
   EEG
   ROUTINE SAMPLING: Showed a diffusely slow and disorganized background
   consisting mostly of mixed theta frequencies. Occasionally, the patient
   reached a low alpha frequency of around 8 Hz but was poorly sustained.
   There were no areas of prominent focal slowing and there were no
   epileptiform features noted.
   SPIKE DETECTION PROGRAMS: There were no entries in these files.
   SEIZURE DETECTION PROGRAMS: There were seven entries in these files.
   These contained chewing artifact and movement artifact but no
   epileptiform features were noted.
   PUSHBUTTON ACTIVATIONS: There were no entries in these files.
   SLEEP: The patient was frequently in and out of stage I and stage II
   sleep and no additional findings were noted.
   CARDIAC MONITOR: Showed a generally regular rhythm with occasional wide
   complex ectopic beats.
   IMPRESSION: This telemetry captured no pushbutton activations. Routine
   sampling showed a diffusely slow and disorganized background consisting
   mostly of mixed theta frequencies. Although the patient did
   occasionally reach a frequency of 8 Hz, this was rather poorly
   sustained. There were no areas of prominent focal slowing and there
   were no epileptiform features noted. Overall, this background is
   suggestive of a mild to moderate encephalopathy. Amongst the most
   common causes of encephalopathy are medications, metabolic
   derangements,
   anoxia, and infection.
   INTERPRETED BY: [**Last Name (LF) **],[**First Name3 (LF) 1358**] L.
   Assessment and Plan
   63 y/o F w/ decompensated Stage IV CHF admitted for inotropic-assisted
   diuresis, with ICU course c/b hypercarbic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation, superimposed sepsis, GI bleeding requiring transfusion,
   persistent pressor requirement, and newly-diagnosed esophageal
   adenocarcinoma.
   .
   # Fluid overload/Congestive heart failure: Fluid overload likely
   multifactorial, related to hypoalbuminemia/poor nutrition in addition
   to heart failure. Diuresing well.
   - continue lasix gtt, as BP tolerates, with goal -1-1.5 L at least for
   the day
   - pt will be transferred to a LTAC that will allow lasix gtt so no need
   to change to bolus
   - follow [**Hospital1 7**] lytes
   .
# Esophageal Adenocarcinoma / GI Bleeding: Patient has had guaiac positive stool
 since admission. Has been transfused a total of 9 units so far, last on [**5-1**]. E
sophageal mass, biopsied [**2144-5-6**], showing adenoCA, T1. After family meeting, pt
made DNR/DNI. Hem/onc consulted for options to treat and stated that given 50% s
urvival benefit with treatment at five years and patient
s poor prognosis from c
ardiac standpoint, any procedure would pose higher risk than benefit.  ERCP was
consulted for possibility of endoscopic ablation, but her adenocarcinoma is too
extensive for endoscopic resection which could pose a 10% risk of complications
that would require surgical repair, which is not an option in her.
   - talk with family about lack of chemotherapeutic and endoscopic
   options for adenocarcinoma and possible need for PEG tube in the future
   for palliation
   - follow Hct,  maintain active T+S
   - holding anticoagulation for now except prophylactic heparin
   - discussed case with Heme/Onc; they will speak with patient
s family
   about her diagnosis
   - f/u Palliative care recs
   .
   # Altered mental status: Mental status continues to improve.
   Non-contrast CT head [**2144-4-14**] showed possible normal pressure
   hydrocephalus, although neurology did not feel that this was the case.
   Consulted neurology on [**5-1**].  LP performed. CSF protein minimally
   elevated but otherwise unremarkable. Culture and cytology negative. EEG
   consistent with encephalopathy. No seizure activity. Most likely
   etiology is toxic/metabolic in the setting of illness and prolonged
   intubation.
   - monitor mental status
   - f/u any neuro recs
   - minimize sedating meds
   .
   # Dysarthria: Likely related to prolonged intubation and recent dental
   extractions.
   .
   # Malnutrition: Malnourished with some improvement with Alb from 1.9 to
   2.2 with hypoalbuminemia contributing to 3^rd spacing. Has been
   difficult to feed patient given mental status, has pulled out multiple
   NGT, now MS improving. So far, trial of taking PO did not result in
   sufficient intake. This will likely continue to worsen over time with
   known esophageal adenocarcinoma.
   -continue ensure
   - need further goals of care discussions with family including PEG tube
   placement at some point
   -f/u palliative care  (appreciate input)
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus, occasional accelerated narrow complex rhythm w/o
   p-waves (?junctional), and NSVT. Pt did have VT/?VF one week ago and
   was shocked out of it by her ICD.
   - Continue amiodarone 200 mg [**Hospital1 7**] for 2 weeks (starting [**2144-5-13**]), then
   200 mg Q day
   - continue telemetry
   - Replete lytes
   # Tachycardia: Sinus tach, low grade. Unclear etiology, consider
   hypovolemia vs CHF.
   -          Monitor
   -          Restarted  BB
   .
   # S/p Dental Extraction: The patient presented with poor dentition. She
   underwent extraction of 24 teeth on [**2144-4-27**]. Culture of surgical
   specimen showing VRE and [**Female First Name (un) **].
   - routine post-operative mouth care
   - RTC Tylenol with morphine for breakthrough (morphine may be
   contributing to pt
s hypotension and AMS, so will try to avoid)
   .
   # MRSA Bacteremia; MRSA/Proteus in sputum: Pt treated with vanc as well
   as cefepime/flagyl. ID recommended 15 day course of cefepime/flagyl,
   which is complete. Recommended 21-day course of vanc for MRSA
   bacteremia, which is also complete.
   .
   # CORONARIES:  CTO of proximal LAD.  CE's negative at OSH.
   - continue aspirin 81mg daily
   - continue zocor
   - restart metoprolol 12.5 [**Hospital1 7**]
   - consider restarting  ACEi (holding for now)
   .
   #  Hypothyroidism: TSH elevated; however free T4 WNL.
   -          continue Synthroid
   -          .
   # Anemia: consider Q week Hct at LTAC

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure who presented with dyspnea and weight gain. He has been admitted to the ICU for inotropic-assisted diuresis. His ICU course has been complicated by hypercarbic respiratory failure requiring intubation, superimposed sepsis, gastrointestinal bleeding requiring transfusion, persistent pressor requirement, and a newly diagnosed esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Potential medical complications:
1. Fluid overload/Congestive heart failure: The patient is likely experiencing fluid overload due to hypoalbuminemia and poor nutrition in addition to his heart failure. Diuretics are being used to manage this condition.
2. Esophageal Adenocarcinoma/GI Bleeding: The patient has been experiencing guaiac-positive stools since admission, indicating gastrointestinal bleeding. He has received multiple blood transfusions. A biopsy of the esophageal mass confirmed adenocarcinoma, and endoscopic ablation is not possible due to the extent of the disease. Chemotherapy and endoscopic options are also not viable, making palliative care recommendations necessary.
3. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status continues to improve. A non-contrast CT head showed possible normal pressure hydrocephalus, but neurology does not believe this is the case. An EEG is consistent with encephalopathy, and most likely etiology is toxic/metabolic in the setting of illness and prolonged int

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure (CHF) who presented with dyspnea and non-productive cough. The patient had a weight gain of 15lbs prior to admission. Outpatient physicians attempted to increase diuretics but were unable to mitigate the weight gain successfully. The patient was transferred to the hospital for inotropic-assisted diuresis. On admission, the patient had hypercarbic respiratory failure requiring intubation, superimposed sepsis, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding requiring transfusion, persistent pressor requirement, and a newly-diagnosed esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Medical Complications:
1. Fluid overload/Congestive heart failure: The patient has fluid overload likely multifactorial, related to hypoalbuminemia/poor nutrition in addition to heart failure. Diuretics are being used to manage this condition.
2. Esophageal Adenocarcinoma/GI Bleeding: The patient has had guaiac positive stool since admission and has received a total of 9 units of transfusion. A biopsy of the esophageal mass showed adenoCA, T1. The patient has made a do not resuscitate/do not intubate (DNR/DNI) decision. Hematology/Oncology consulted for treatment options but stated that given the patient's poor prognosis from a cardiac standpoint, any procedure would pose higher risk than benefit. Endoscopic

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old woman with a history of chronic heart failure who was admitted to the ICU for decompensated heart failure and inotropic-assisted diuresis. She presented with dyspnea, a 15-pound weight gain, and non-productive cough. Outpatient physicians attempted to increase her diuretics but were unable to control her weight gain. The patient is now being transferred to a long-term acute care (LTAC) facility.

During her ICU stay, the patient developed several medical complications. She required intubation for hypercarbic respiratory failure, had a superimposed sepsis, underwent transfusion for gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, required persistent pressor support, and was diagnosed with esophageal adenocarcinoma. The patient has also had a possible normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), altered mental status (AMS) likely due to toxic/metabolic encephalopathy, dysarthria related to prolonged intubation and dental extractions, malnutrition, rhythm disturbances including sinus tachycardia and nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT), and a history of ventricular fibrillation (VF) treated with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD).

The patient's current medications include amiodarone for rhythm control, diuretics for fluid overload, and Synthroid for hypothyroidism. She has been treated with vancomycin and cefepime

   Assessment and Plan
   63 y/o F w/ decompensated Stage IV CHF admitted for inotropic-assisted
   diuresis, with ICU course c/b hypercarbic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation, superimposed sepsis, GI bleeding requiring transfusion,
   persistent pressor requirement, and newly-diagnosed esophageal
   adenocarcinoma.
   .
   # Fluid overload/Congestive heart failure: Fluid overload likely
   multifactorial, related to hypoalbuminemia/poor nutrition in addition
   to heart failure. Diuresing well.
   - continue lasix gtt, as BP tolerates, with goal -1-1.5 L at least for
   the day
   - pt will be transferred to a LTAC that will allow lasix gtt so no need
   to change to bolus
   - follow [**Hospital1 7**] lytes
   .
# Esophageal Adenocarcinoma / GI Bleeding: Patient has had guaiac positive stool
 since admission. Has been transfused a total of 9 units so far, last on [**5-1**]. E
sophageal mass, biopsied [**2144-5-6**], showing adenoCA, T1. After family meeting, pt
made DNR/DNI. Hem/onc consulted for options to treat and stated that given 50% s
urvival benefit with treatment at five years and patient
s poor prognosis from c
ardiac standpoint, any procedure would pose higher risk than benefit.  ERCP was
consulted for possibility of endoscopic ablation, but her adenocarcinoma is too
extensive for endoscopic resection which could pose a 10% risk of complications
that would require surgical repair, which is not an option in her.
   - talk with family about lack of chemotherapeutic and endoscopic
   options for adenocarcinoma and possible need for PEG tube in the future
   for palliation
   - follow Hct,  maintain active T+S
   - holding anticoagulation for now except prophylactic heparin
   - discussed case with Heme/Onc; they will speak with patient
s family
   about her diagnosis
   - f/u Palliative care recs
   .
   # Altered mental status: Mental status continues to improve.
   Non-contrast CT head [**2144-4-14**] showed possible normal pressure
   hydrocephalus, although neurology did not feel that this was the case.
   Consulted neurology on [**5-1**].  LP performed. CSF protein minimally
   elevated but otherwise unremarkable. Culture and cytology negative. EEG
   consistent with encephalopathy. No seizure activity. Most likely
   etiology is toxic/metabolic in the setting of illness and prolonged
   intubation.
   - monitor mental status
   - f/u any neuro recs
   - minimize sedating meds
   .
   # Dysarthria: Likely related to prolonged intubation and recent dental
   extractions.
   .
   # Malnutrition: Malnourished with some improvement with Alb from 1.9 to
   2.2 with hypoalbuminemia contributing to 3^rd spacing. Has been
   difficult to feed patient given mental status, has pulled out multiple
   NGT, now MS improving. So far, trial of taking PO did not result in
   sufficient intake. This will likely continue to worsen over time with
   known esophageal adenocarcinoma.
   -continue ensure
   - need further goals of care discussions with family including PEG tube
   placement at some point
   -f/u palliative care  (appreciate input)
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus, occasional accelerated narrow complex rhythm w/o
   p-waves (?junctional), and NSVT. Pt did have VT/?VF one week ago and
   was shocked out of it by her ICD.
   - Continue amiodarone 200 mg [**Hospital1 7**] for 2 weeks (starting [**2144-5-13**]), then
   200 mg Q day
   - continue telemetry
   - Replete lytes
   # Tachycardia: Sinus tach, low grade. Unclear etiology, consider
   hypovolemia vs CHF.
   -          Monitor
   -          Restarted  BB
   .
   # S/p Dental Extraction: The patient presented with poor dentition. She
   underwent extraction of 24 teeth on [**2144-4-27**]. Culture of surgical
   specimen showing VRE and [**Female First Name (un) **].
   - routine post-operative mouth care
   - RTC Tylenol with morphine for breakthrough (morphine may be
   contributing to pt
s hypotension and AMS, so will try to avoid)
   .
   # MRSA Bacteremia; MRSA/Proteus in sputum: Pt treated with vanc as well
   as cefepime/flagyl. ID recommended 15 day course of cefepime/flagyl,
   which is complete. Recommended 21-day course of vanc for MRSA
   bacteremia, which is also complete.
   .
   # CORONARIES:  CTO of proximal LAD.  CE's negative at OSH.
   - continue aspirin 81mg daily
   - continue zocor
   - restart metoprolol 12.5 [**Hospital1 7**]
   - consider restarting  ACEi (holding for now)
   .

   -          .

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old woman with a history of chronic heart failure (CHF) who was admitted for inotropic-assisted diuresis. She presented with dyspnea, non-productive cough, and a 15-pound weight gain. Outpatient physicians attempted to increase her diuretics but were unsuccessful in mitigating her weight gain. The patient was transferred to the ICU for further management.

The patient's medical history includes decompensated stage IV CHF, esophageal adenocarcinoma, gastrointestinal bleeding requiring transfusion, persistent pressor requirement, hypercarbic respiratory failure requiring intubation, and superimposed sepsis. She also has altered mental status, dysarthria, malnutrition, rhythm disturbances, tachycardia, and poor dentition with a dental extraction.

The patient has been treated with various medications including diuretics, inotropes, antibiotics, and antiarrhythmics. She has received blood transfusions and has undergone an endoscopic evaluation of her esophageal mass, which showed adenocarcinoma. The patient has also had cultures obtained from her tissue and cerebrospinal fluid, which were negative for infection.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 103 bpm, blood pressure of 94/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 96% on room air, and a sinus tachycardia rhythm. Her fluid balance shows a negative balance of 959 mL.

The patient's laboratory results indicate abnormalities in her white blood cell count, hemoglobin, platelet count, electrolytes, kidney function, liver function, and nutritional status. Imaging studies have revealed a possible normal pressure hydrocephalus on a non-contrast CT scan of the head.

The patient's medical complications include fluid overload/congestive heart failure, esophageal adenocarcinoma/GI bleeding, altered mental status, dysarthria, malnutrition, rhythm disturbances, tachycardia, and poor dentition. The patient has completed courses of antibiotics for MRSA bacteremia and a combination of cefepime and flagyl for MRSA/Proteus in the sputum.

The patient's care plan includes continuing diuretics for fluid overload, providing nutritional support, minimizing sedating medications, considering a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement for palliation, and discussing end-of-life care options with the family.

The patient's prognosis is poor due to her multiple comorbidities and the advanced stage of her esophageal adenocarcinoma. Further discussion regarding code status, rehabilitation, and disposition will be conducted with the family.
